awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Costs and Advantages of a Novel Sodium Channel Mutation in Copepods
awd_abstract_narration: Toxic algal blooms pose a threat to fisheries and public health. A key issue for understanding the effects of toxic algae on aquatic ecosystems is how grazers evolve adaptations to algal toxins. Adaptation of copepods (the most abundant multicellular animals in the sea) to microalgae that produce potent neurotoxins (called saxitoxins, STX) has been previously demonstrated. STX blocks sodium (Na+) channels and interrupt nerve transmission signal. A novel mutation that is located in the inner portion of the Na+ channel, and leads to persistent electrical currents when the channel is inactivated (i.e., a leaky channel), has been identified. Leaky channels result in unintended nerve transmission signals and cell hypersensitivity; hence, they are considered to be very costly to individuals. However, it is hypothesized that in the presence of STX, the leaky channel mutation is advantageous because STX blockage of leaky channels reduces the likelihood of unintended nerve transmission signals and cell hypersensitivity. This project represents an interdisciplinary collaboration between labs at University of Connecticut and the University of Florida with expertise in molecular techniques, neurobiology, and zooplankton ecology and evolution. Expected results are: 1) Development of genetic markers for specifically detecting wild and mutant Na+ channels in individual copepods, 2) Neurophysiological characterization of the functional properties of the mutant Na+ channel and its responses to STX, 3) Quantification of the costs and benefits to individuals bearing the mutation responsible for the leaky Na+ channel. This research can potentially lead to the demonstration of a new molecular mechanism of neurotoxin adaptation, and inform a variety of fields of research from neurobiology to ecology and evolution.  The broader impacts of this research are: 1) New key information for predicting whether grazers can control toxic blooms and toxin transfer to fish and shellfish. 2) Collaboration with professional educators to translate results from this study and the toxin adaptation literature into prepared curricular materials that meet national science standards. The material will be made widely available via a website and workshops presented at conference meetings of scientists and secondary educators. 3) Presentations in lecture series aimed at lay audiences. 4) Training of undergraduate and graduate students in an interdisciplinary environment.

por.por_cntn:
One major challenge to biologists is understanding how organisms adapt to their environment. In nature, many prey are toxic, yet animals have adapted to eating these toxic prey. Such is the case in the ocean, where some algae produce neurotoxins that paralyze the animals that eat them. It has been demonstrated, however, that some populations of animals (copepods) can effectively cope with these toxic algae.

 The overarching goal of this project was to test the hypothesis that a novel mutation in the  sodium channel of the copepod Acartia hudsonica conferred tolerance to the neurotoxins (saxitoxins) produced by the dinoflagellate genus Alexandrium (organisms are shown in the accompanying figure).  Our accomplishments included:

1) We developed a new method for achieving high quality RNA for copepod transcriptomic studies. 

2) We cloned and sequence the voltage-gated sodium channel in a marine copepod, Acartia hudsonica. To our knowledge, this is the first such record for a crustacean.

3) We discovered a novel mutation in the copepod sodium channel that results from a case of gene splicing. To our knowledge, this is the first such report for a marine invertebrate.  

4) We characterized the effect of the mutation on the function of the copepod sodium channel. 

5) We measured the advantages and costs of the mutation in the copepod sodium channel to copepod fitness. 

This project provided training for two Ph.D. students and one postdoctoral associate. In addition, the project provided research experience for several undergraduates. 

The results from this project have been communicated to the academic community through several peer-reviewed publications, and through two Ph.D. dissertations. In addition, results were communicated through conference presentations, and academic seminars.  

Impact of this research on society beyond science and engineering: Toxic algal blooms are proliferating at unprecedented rates worldwide. Our understanding of the factors that promote and determinate these blooms, and the effects of blooms on aquatic consumers is very limited.  One important, but poorly understood factor in bloom control is whether and how animals adapt to the neurotoxins born by algae.   This study resulted in several novel discoveries and ruled out a possible mechanism of adaptation to toxins. The implication is that there exist several mechanisms of adaptation to neurotoxins. One immediate application is that toxin accumulation in more toxin tolerant animals is not necessarily as a consequence of copepod adaptation to the toxic prey.

We also reached nonacademic audiences through our educational and outreach efforts. We ran a workshop at the 2010 conference of the National Science Teachers Association (NSTA). The workshop provided materials and ideas for high school teachers to develop research-based curricular material to incorporate active learning activities using the concept of grazer adaptation to neurotoxic prey. More recently, we have made these materials available online (http://datanuggets.org/2014/08/dangerous-aquatic-prey-can-predators-adapt-to-toxic-algae/).

Our research was also featured as part of a TV documentary series (Infestation: Water, http://www.stornowayproductions.com/productions/infestation/).
